properties.media:imagetext:
Monday
Janue ry 9, 1950
Today we
got off to en 3:00 &.M. start by
cer - a
Chrysler - to a most wonderful experience.
We drove along
the road
which
leads to Beirut in Lebanon and about half way turned north behind
the coastal range and on to Baalbek,
an old Roman ruin which should be -
we all
think - as well known as eny historic place.
It was built on
the most tremendous plan and took over two hundred years and as many
thousands of slaves to complete.
It is in a truly remarkable state of
preservation.
The first structure was built around 200 B.C. and
the
whole temple wes finally completed
around
500 A.D.
Some idea of its
size can be gained by the fact that the stairs lesding to the temple
were 150' wide and the great courtyard approximately 100 yards in
each direction.
One of
the buildings - the temple of Bacchus - des-
cribed as
"perhaps the most beautiful
of all the temples surviving
from Roman times" is in a good state of
preservation.
Even a
small
part of the roof is still in place.
The whole place is fascinating,
but it would take a
small book to describe it properly.
However, one
item will
give you some idea
of the prodigious effort
expended.
Many of the
columns were fashioned
from limestone in a quarry within
sight of the temple.
Others were made of granite.
There is no
granite in this part of the morld, but the archaeologists found a
quarry in Egypt where these thirty-ton pillars were produced.
The
pillars - which,
by the way, were decorated after they were put in
place - were
carried on barges down the Nile, landed at Tyre in
southern Lebanon and
rolled to Baalbek more than one hundred miles
along a road built for that purpose.
So much for Baalbek.
You will hear more about it from
air travelers after we inaugurste service to Beirut.
In order to
have a look at the latter city and its modern sirport now under con-
struction we
drove over there.
The airport is & long way from
complete but will be the best in this part of the world.
The city
is often called "Little Paris".
It is built along the blue Medi-
terranean shore with mountains rising three or four thousand feet
in
the background.
There are several attractive seaside resort
hotels at one of which - the St. George
- we had tea and
picked up
a few shells on the beach.
(For you collectors - no good ones !)
Driving back to Demascus "e got into a dense fog up in
the mountsins, but fortunately our Arab driver was good
and
vie got
home about 8:00 p.m. all agreeing thet we have seen a lot
considering
that we left Brussels only Saturday night and this is Monday!
Will try to get off another family letter from Delhi.
As ever,
–Ω. M. B.
P.S.
We thought that Damascus - surrounded by desert - would be
werm but it was plenty cold and ve nearly froze at Baalbek.
Hebe
wore three sweaters, one of my coats, all her own coats ana a rain-
coat on top of it all and still was cold!
